Yasuo's double crit passive is not and has never been why he's been difficult to balance. His shield, ult, wind wall, and high early game offensive power are why he's been given so much attention. Hell, his crit steroid is pretty much the only part of his kit that's easy to balance; it gives him incentive to itemize for crit earlier in the game, limiting his possible build paths, and it gives him consistent damage output later in the game, compared to other crit building champs that sometimes hit you for 350 and other times hit you for 1000. The passive gives him sharper powerspikes compared to other champions, but that doesn't mean its harder to balance. The shield, by comparison, is far more problematic, and has gotten nerfed over and over for that reason.
i say let him have the shield lotsa champs have shields. screw the passive thats what needs to change it does way to much consistant damage after 2 items

Mine has to be that you have to be mobile in order to be strong. Personally, I thought mobility was a trade off for something. Guess I was wrong.
I'd further define that one as: "Champions with mobility don't have to pay enough for it in terms of their power in other areas."
Much better wording lol, except it is: "Champions with mobility don't have to pay AT ALL for it in terms of their power in other areas."

point and click is evil

traditional supports aren't allowed to do damage, be relevant or go lane solo. (i hate tank supports)

The fact that they balance "normal" champions in relation to other normal champions, but leave the really extreme outliers alone and untouched.

When a champion is clearly toxic to the game and needs more than a simple numbers nerf, but they find it too hard to decide what to change, so they leave them alone and untouched for years without any changes.

That, once they have settled on a kit for a champion, they will (almost) never change that kit, regardless of how badly-designed it is, or even if it completely contradicts their core design principles.

The thing I hate the most?

That's easy.

Resourceless/Energy champions with any combination of the following:
**Medium to long range poke**
**Shields**
**Heals**

Why?  Because this allows them to attrition down opponents with actual resources without having to worry about cost on their end.  Champions with these type of abilities tend to be obnoxious as hell to balance properly.

And by the by, while Vlad does in fact have HP costs, his Q fits the above criteria to a T.
But let's be fair. Vlad's early game is so trash he's a garbage can-not, rather than a garbage can.

Vlad early game is only bad if you go all-in before level 7. 

If you are good with Vlad it's literally impossible to solo lose lane against 90% of the champion pool (other than Swain, Fiddle and other monstrosities whose harass go through Vlad's pool).

Tell me the last time they made any big change to vladimir directly? When was the last big buff that made him this monster that everyone hates? Aside from some QoL changes in season 4 and a couple minor changes in Season 3 there is nothing that has pushed him to being a monster, but before this season he was nothing and no one even looked at vlad.

The only thing is many people are starting to take him mid where Ignite is still very common. I think your analysis of why he is "stronger" is in line, but the summoner spell doesn't seem to be the issue with him being in mid. I could just not be putting the power of top laners early   higher than what it is compared to mid laners early.

It's also worth mentioning that while not everyone liked it or bought it, with the removal of Executioner's Calling there's less answers for leech champions outside of group burst. 

I think a lot of Vladimir's success mid might be related to the fact that high HP pools tend to counter burst champions (think {{champion:36}} ) and since he still gains AP for building that health he may have a good place there. 

I will say I am speaking from inexperience in seeing him in the mid-lane though, I am not seeing that much in NA Plat level, I think there are probably some issues with taking him mid over top that might arise being that Vladimir's roam is not the best, especially early, he's pretty much a late game hyper carry where you really only get a lot of power out of his roam from his damage amp ultimate (great for dragons though). Unlike some assassin mids though he's not going to go sneak into bot and 2 shot someone. The lack of mana could be oppressive to some mana starved champions though.

I'll have to wait til I see this more to pass judgement on it, but thanks for mentioning it as I completely ignored the possibility.

Champions with incredible scaling that are also lane bullies. This has got to be one of the most frustrating things I have ever seen in LoL. To be bullied around by a champion that scales incredibly well into the late game is so disheartening to play against. 


{{champion:268}} {{champion:157}} {{champion:69}}{{champion:13}} 
- Pre-nerf Azir was an incredible lane bully with very good scaling, and it was super frustrating to play against
- Yasuo before the base health nerf was able to bully a lot of match ups, as well as having an incredible late game
- Cass after the rework
- Ryze before his nerfs in season 4. Had an entirely point and click kit, which lended to his ability to also lane bully you. Incredibly annoying.

For me, if you choose a champion that has an incredible late game, the trade off should be that they are weak early game, or in the very least shouldn't be able to heavily bully people in lane. There needs to be a risk vs. reward. For example, every time I choose Nasus, I'm risking having a horrendous early game for the chance I can stay safe, get stacks, and take it to mid + late game where I can dish out damage.

Rito's balancing methodology?

I would be lying to say I never get excited about who is gonna be next to receive the clubbing in the face whenever a new patch is released.

And that itself honesty, is pretty sad aye.

But my most hated balancing methodology is definitely their severe lack of communication inside the company where what their right arm does can sometimes just outright contradicts with what its left arm's doing. I won't even try to be satirical and call it my "favourite" since I just absolutely HATE everything about it.

Seriously, it feels like the balance "team" is just a bunch of guys who independently choose random champs, shift random numbers until they get 50% winrate in internal playtests, then push them onto the next patch. There doesn't ever seem to be a particular focus in every patch, just small adjustments whose impact is difficult to appreciate.

It's even worse when they put a few small nerfs over a few patches and the community gets incited into "HURR BETTER NURF JINX XD" or "gj riot i played 50000 games of lb n shes literally unplayable". Which results in fear of community backlash, which results in even softer changes that feel like they accomplish nothing.

Also, it feels like they have no influence, or choose not to influence the tuning of new champs and reworks. Like, who was the last champion whose numbers were not immediately changed within 2 patches? Vel'koz?

Or "let's make resourceless champs even better by gutting mana regen for all champs across the board and try to ignore the fact that they already had enough advantages before"{{champion:238}}{{champion:64}}

Hm, I would say I dislike it when Riot makes a champion who can max a single ability and get the most damage/waveclear/utility/survivability from that single ability. Fizz is perhaps the worst offender here. Maxxing E gives him waveclear, mobility, survivability, utility, and daamge all at once.

Slightly related: champions who have extream waveclear tied to their primary damage ability. Consider that in S2 Morgana was considered top-tier waveclear, and she had to forego maxxing Q to do that. Now we have the likes of Ziggs/Xerath/Zed/Fizz/Ahri/ect. who max a single ability and get strong waveclear along with high damage output.
When a champion has health costs and those costs might as well not be there for all the shits the champ gives about them.
{{champion:8}} ?

Least favorite is "we are going to compensate". Then they don't listen. Ahri players (like myself, mages are not working so she is on the backburner) got a movespeed steroid on our Q and REDUCED acquisition range on our W/R in exchange for losing DFG and losing our charm damage boost. All we wanted was correct targeting, which it did, and a  DAMAGE boost on our Q since we farm with it. =/

tl;dr: Compensation buffs are a lie.

Oh and lets not mention Veigar ofc.
Ahri mains have no room to complain, they made her kit ridiculous. Her q might as well be a dash she moves so fast and she doesn't even have to target half of her damage.

Please explain. A move increase that doesn't let me cross terrain (see Ekko, Lb, Zed, Corki, Ezreal...everyone...with non ultimate terrain crosses). My "auto target" damage is not only negligible, it requires me to go into 450 range (standard adc range is 5(!)50) and I assure you thats a big deal to a SQUISHY mage. I'm lost how you think she's overpowered enough that we can't "have room to complain". All I said was I'd happily trade what she went through JUST to get more damage loaded onto her Q. Honestly, I'd personally enjoy a revert.  She is meant to land a charm and grab people, then be ~REWARDED~ for doing so. Now? You land a charm, it hardly matters. Its just another lob of cc. Its like "why bother using this high mana cost, mediocre damage, hard cc with a brief duration". Sorry for the rant. Its just.... I'm tired of this. I want her kit to reward you for how iconic it was intended to be. Cass gets rewarded for poison with LOW low cooldown twin fang, urgot the same thing (with his...pill?), Darius gets rewarded for bleed stacks because his ult does more damage. Ahri? No reward. Iconic kit attribute...trashed for "reasons". =/

Again sorry for the rant. I just hated the rollercoaster and I wished all they had done to her ORIGINAL kit was boost her Q damage, or make her charm worthwhile. I got neither. I got movespeed, and a requirement to be in range to get murdered to use half my kits intended damage. =/ Have a nice day, third apology. Got carried away.

Mine has to be Riot's inaction regarding anti-interactive champion kits.  By this I mean champions whose sole purpose is to just stop their opponent from ever being able to do anything or specifically benefit from not interacting.

{{champion:17}} - Widely known to be horrible to play against, not particularly strong in any areas, never really changed since beta.  Runner-up for most anti-interactive champion.
{{champion:83}} - Possibly the most anti-interactive champion in the entire game, mechanics never changed since release.  Ghouls will follow enemy champions a good thousand units without even needing to target them, AoE, healing, etc.
{{champion:28}} - Her reworked passive is basically "enemies pay more for wards and minions can't see me", she's almost always either brokenly strong or useless.
{{champion:27}} - He's less egregious than Teemo or Yorick, but his playstyle either revolves around proxying (by definition completely ignoring everyone in the game) or just running around being annoying.
Riot has admitted Yorick is toxic and have taken him off the free week rotation because of that, they don't want a lot of Yorick players out there
That's exactly what I mean by inaction, yes.  Riot knows he's super toxic and leaves him in his current state for years.

How on Earth did you not include Nasus in that list? His Q encourages Nasus to be as non-interactive as possible, and every other part of his kit discourages his opponents from interacting with him. His passive discourages poking him. His point and click W is both a major threat if the enemy jungler is around and basically an auto-win button against AA reliant champs. His E is a gigantic "can't fight in this area, especially if you have minion aggro." His ult is "Trying to all-in? Nasus now has bonus HP, your taking more %HP damage than Elise with max CDR can output, and Nasus is gaining bonus AD the longer this fight lasts." Not to mention his Q lets him rush a major CDR/defnsive item first, further discouraging you from trying to attack him and further encouraging him to jsut farm away.

In case anyone missed it, I kinda dislike Nasus as a champ.

On every point I agree, but I also think he does have some decent lane dynamics at the same time.  Part of Teemo and Yorick's frustration is that they maintain their absurdity from range, whereas Nasus does kinda need to be in your face to get anything done.

I think Wither is one of the most anti-interactive abilities in the game on its own, but Nasus does kinda need that utility to remain relevant.  Good design?  Maybe not, but he's also not inherently negative to play against in most matchups.
